Spent most of 2012 assembling a 3d printer from salvaged printer and PC bits.  Successfully printed 3 objects during December 2012 and have since been brushing up software skills.
The .stl files were imported into Blender and combined. I also rendered the image shown above. 
The .stl file for the Thinker comes from lampmaker on Thingiverse who got the file from MIT CSAIL database and the file for the Fountain is from robmyers  on Thingiverse who commissioned it from dustycloud.org.

Untested .stl files, as in I have not yet analysed them for unholiness and the resultiing Gcode files have not been built on a 3d printer as of 26thJan2013. Replaced the .stl file with one that has some content on Sunday Jan 27th. Updates in the next two weeks when I have had a go at printing the file. 6th March 2013
Printout complete but having difficulty cooling the extruded filament quickly enough for it not to droop with my printer.
The stl file has been redone so that now the Thinker is sat in the Fountain and this prints okay , except for the tubes at either end,with an overall length of 10cm, see pic. Netffab-basic was used to check and repair the .stl file.

title: Naze32 Rev5 FunFly & Acro Flight Controller 2g Cover

description.text:
1mm thick Naze32 Rev5 Flight Controller Thin Cover, edges are 3mm
Weight 2g
Designed to be as light as possible (2g) and works with both the Naze32 FunFly and Acro Rev5 flight controllers.
Two styles, a compete cover & one with LED cutout with an plug that can be inserted so you can print the cover in an opaque filament, and the plug in a transparent filament.
Even includes a .4mm indention inside for BARO for FunFly version.
Works with standard 8mm nylon standoffs.
Included a MakerWare versions (x3g) of the LED Plug with an included "helper" disk since the size is tiny 4.8mm x 1.8mm
If you print the standard cover in transparent filament, the LEDs show through very nicely, see image 3.
If there are enough requests I will make a version with the additional pins.
Will work with straight or right angle ESC pins.
Not compatible with any DJI frame.

.2mm layer height
2 shells

title: ShipBuilder Starter Set
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
1-21-2015 Update: I've added individual files for most of the components - they may require re-sizing based on your individual printer, enjoy. Everything you need to build your own custom spaceship, all printed together on one convenient plate. Command decks, cargo pods, communication arrays, engines, structural supports, and living quarters are all included, along with two display stands and clips to hold three lengths of 1.75 mm filament for assembly.
Update: Added a lower resolution version for easier handling.
Update 2: Added a looser fitting version for easier assembly. EDIT: Thanks for "featuring"! I guess I'll have to hurry up on set 2. If you're looking to have a copy of this printed locally, consider checking out 3D Hubs: http://www.3dhubs.com/san-francisco/hubs/kevin
Printed on a Rep2 with low settings. You may need to scale the model up a few percent to ensure a good fit with your printer settings.

title: Parametric box with QR code for link

description.text: Print a box to hold a given number of items of a specified size. Git repository: http://github.com/l0b0/parametric-box Version 2 contains the QR code embedded in the back plate. This is a demo of http://github.com/l0b0/qr2scad, which was slapped together today to enable this sort of thing dynamically. If someone sees the QR code on your thing in real life, they can find the design and make their own copies with just a photo of it. Theoretically, you could even assign this job to a machine, looking around the web (or your tool box) for things that can be duplicated. Another possibility would be to encode the .scad file in a QR code (after using http://github.com/l0b0/OpenSCAD-Minimizer) and include that on the model. Nicely Von Neumann-friendly :)

• Open in OpenSCAD.
  • Uncomment one of the Size configuration sections. Dimensions for CD and DVD covers are provided.
  • Set the items variable to the desired amount.
  • Set wall_thickness if you want to.
  • Check the size of the resulting model before printing!

Miscellaneous add-on parts for BAH Nemesis:
  • Solid Front/Rear Sidewalls - Hide and protect forward components
  • Rear Sidewalls - Design allows for air flow and holds bulkhead
  • Rear Bulkhead - Easily replaceable and expendable part to mount SMA antenna.
  • Antenna Tube pivots (coming soon) - Allows folding protection of whisker antennas found on FrSky D4R-II. See stacking Rx tray.
  • Utility Plate - 36x36x1.5mm general plate for insulating PDB from CF frame... or general use.
    • Print Instructions:
  • Use brim to help sidewalls adhere to printbed. Lower fan settings and allow sidewalls to cool after print to reduce warping.
  • Extra print tabs designed on Rear Sidewall STL for better adhesion, again use brims. Remove print tabs before installing on Nemesis.
    • Install instructions:
  • Slip the sidewalls over the existing standoffs
  • Rear sidewalls have cutouts at bottom for clearance of bobbin screw & hex nut.
  • Rear bulkhead slides into the sidewalls. Separately printed and detachable for easy replacement if damaged in a crash.
  • Antenna Pivots require an M3 hole in the middle of the first battery strap slot (as the plate narrows). Use a M3 screw and hex nut, optionally a lock washer helps to keep tension on the pivot. if using lock washer, a nylon washer between the pivot and top plate can help movement while holding position.
    • Usage Instructions:
    Antenna Pivots are designed to be installed so that the antenna tubes fold to a stowaway position above the plate. Open fully (butt against top plate) to create a consistent V-shaped horizontal right angle.

Print Instructions:
  • Use brim to help the sidewalls to adhere to the bed.
  • Extra print tabs designed on Rear Sidewall STL for better adhesion, again use brims. Remove print tabs before installing on Nemesis.
    • Install instructions:
  • Slip the sidewalls over the existing standoffs
  • Rear sidewalls have cutouts at bottom for clearance of bobbin screw & hex nut.
  • Rear bulkhead slides into the sidewalls. Seperate print for easy replacement on crash.
  • Antenna Pivots require an M3 hole in the middle of the battery strap slot.
    Usage Instructions:
    Antenna Pivots are designed to be installed so that the antenna tubes fold to a stowaway position above the plate. Open fully (but against top plate) to create a V-shaped horizontal right angle.

title: Printable STL Printrbot Adjustable Spool Coaster
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my printable stl conversion of Printrbot's Open Source Adjustable Spool Coaster. Based on Printrbot's original DXF lasercut design that is posted here:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/printrbot-adjustable-spool-coaster
It is designed to hold almost any size spool of Filament. Just slide it as wide or as thin as your spool and lock down the 3mm bolts.
Assembly instructions can be found at Printrbot:
http://help.printrbot.com/c/Acrylic_Adjustable_Spool_Coaster
This version is an earlier version (I believe) that uses pins to hold the 608zz Bearings instead of bolts. Any trouble, just look at my assembled pics.
This is based on the original DXF files and is designed to use all of the original hardware as listed in Printrbot's BOM. It has been modified from a cutting DXF to allow it to be built up (printed). The tabs/sockets, screw and nut channels have been modded to allow it to be printed and assembled with a tight fit. The goal is to have well fitting parts with little or no machining to make them fit.
I had excellent results on my printrbot simple using .20 mm height, .4mm nozzle, 30% infill and only 2 perimeters.
My prints fit really nice and tight with my setup. I suggest you print 2 parts that attach to each other and see if you have good results with your setup.The final print height is 5.6mm to allow the tabs/sockets to remain as close as possible to the original pattern. If your tabs/sockets are loose fitting, go to 3 perimeters or imports the files into tinkercad and extrude the height to 5.8 or higher.
Feel free to mod, edit and share. But please give credit when due. and please share your results or any problems to further this project. Enjoy!
See photos here or the original assembly instructions at Printrbot Support (link provided in description.)

comments.text: haha! I meant the metal made (Aluminum I believe) extruder you have in the pictures. Diagrams maybe?

The nozzle is turned from a 5/16-24 stainless bolt, the inside is step drilled from 4mm to accept the PTFE tubing to 1.75mm at the heating block and 0.35mm at the end.  To secure the tube a 1/8 tube fitting can be drilled to 4mm and threaded onto the bolt with a 4mm ferrule (I made a ferrule from aluminum). A normal heating block is made to thread onto the bolt.  The top end of the bolt, below the tube fitting, threads into a cooling block that will support the nozzle.  See the provided nozzle file for shape reference.  If I find some extra time I will make drawings and post.

The positional accuracy can be quite

The largest issue is backlash in the rod ends. This can be
compensated for by applying preload in the direction of the
connecting rods with a total magnitude in the range of two times the
mass of the end effector.

title: BB King - the 3D Printed Roller Bearing

description.text: My new YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCnnw56J_TeOsF4M_F5pPPJQ Is friction giving you the blues? BB King is here to help! This is a proof-of-concept print to evaluate using standard BB bullets as the rolly bits in a 3D printed bearing. I'll be using what I learned from this in some projects I have coming up! VIDEO: http://youtu.be/3pl6-AXtWZY I'm using 6 mm plastic BB bullets and I printed my prototype in ABS at .1 mm layer height, 10% in-fill and with 3 shells on my original Replicator. I had to scale the model up a hair and that is reflected in my THING file. The STL files are original scale. ENJOY! If you like what I do and want to help me do more, please consider supporting me on my Patreon page! http://www.patreon.com/ErikJDurwoodII Thanks!

Print - you may have to scale up the model if you don't use my THING file or you have a different size of BBs.
Load - Fit as many as you can leaving one out to fit the key in.
Lock - slide the key in to long the bearing tight.

title: Replacement sistema food storage container clip

description.text:
I'm not sure if these "Sistema" food containers are just in Australia and New Zealand. They are really good, but have always had 2 points of weakness. One of those points is where the clip attaches to the container, on 2 small hooks, on the container itself. When the container breaks here, there's not a whole lot that can be done to repair it. The other point of weakness is the clip that holds the lid on breaks at the hinge point, on the clip. We have plenty of the containers in the cupboard, and enough have broken clips that I decided to spend the time to draw up a replacement. From my research, there are two types of clips:
1) the clip is attached to the container body, coming in three different sizes, where the clip itself is flat
2) the clip attaches to the container lid, only seems to come in one size, where the clip itself is curved This replacement is for the former type of clip. I drew it up in OpenSCAD, making the code parametric. If you come across another clip size, either let me know and I'll add it, or just extend this thing yourself. Maybe one day I'll get around to doing some work on the curved style clip.

I'm not sure if it's my printer is dodgy at overhangs, but try as I might, I just could NOT get a nice curve on the back of the clip. To solve this, I have added some support.
If you don't like, or don't need the support, open the scad file & comment out the support, at the end of the code. If you want to use the scad, or modify it, you will need the pandpp module as well, which contains some maths functions I needed for drawing the circles & fillets. Once printed, be sure to measure & clean up the diameter of the small diameter rod. It NEEDS to be 3mm. Any bigger, and you are very likely to break the container, which I haven't found a fix for yet. Clean up with a sharp knife.

description.text: Just something I threw together for my Rostock printer to help keep any vibrations of the rods down. I am using carbon fiber rods that are about 5.5mm diameter. I picked up the springs at local hardware store. The printed pieces are about 21mm center to center so that leaves about a 33mm gap (with about 75mm distance between rods) for the spring. The springs I used were not too strong and about 20mm long.

Print 6 pieces. Add a spring between each then snap onto the rods.
(Added second variation that would clip on at a different angle and have a less chance of pulling off).

description.text:
Project dropped in favor of a better multi-platform choice:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:119350 This is my version of a simple OpenSCAD editor. I run Linux and all of the current editors are for Windows or OSX. I decided to use node-webkit and CodeMirror Editor to make an all systems compatible editor.

Goto my Github page for the latest downloads and updates:
https://github.com/iceblu3710/OpenSCAD_Editor Features:
  • Available on Linux, Mac OSX and Windows
  • Autoformatting, Block Comment/Uncomment
  • Code folding
  • Syntax highlighting (In progress)
  • Find & Replace (In progress, needs UI)
  • Autocomplete (Implementation only)
    • Instructions:
  • Download one of the node-webkit prebuilt binaries (v0.4.0 â€” Jan 18, 2013)
  • Open/Install OpenSCAD and in the menu select View -> Hide Editor and Design -> Automatic Reload and Compile
  • Unzip the node-webkit binary and cut/copy the nw.exe and nw.pak files into the OpenSCAD editor folder
  • Run nw.exe and open a .scad file in both the editor AND in OpenSCAD itself
  • Whenever you make changes in the editor press F5 or Ctrl-S and OpenSCAD will render the changes

title: Idler For Short Bolts for Airtripper Bowden Extruder

description.text:
I was previously using some M3x40 bolts for tensioning the idler on my Airtripper extruder, but needed to scavenge the long bolts for a different project. This idler was designed to allow for the use of shorter bolts. I'm currently using 30 mm bolts with springs, but you could use shorter ones (down to ~20 mm) depending on if you're using springs and their sizes. Hope that this might help someone else.
This Thing was modified from the "Airtripper Bowden Extruder BSP Edition" Thing, but should fit most variants of the Airtripper Extruder.

As requested in the comments, the lip for the tensioning bolts has been extended and a recessed spot for the washer/spring has been added. I haven't printed this, but it should print fine. Download the R001 files for this version. The photo has not been updated.
Sliced with 0.2 mm layer height, 3 perimeters, and 50% infill.

This is a small part to create a simple waterpump powered by air.  
I printed mine using the following settings 0.3mm layer with 10% infill. Under no circumstance use supports those would just be in the way and it will not function properly.  
Also a attached pipe is a must this is just the core part of the complete pump, but a pipe can be organized easier the this piece.

Use the main piece and attach a aripump by connecting it to the 6mm hole on the side. Take a PVC pipe with 16mm outside diameter which can be directly plugged into to upper hole. Submerge the thing and let the pipe stick out of the water a bit. power on the airpump and there you go a simple waterpump.
I also attached 2 adapters fitting into the 16mm hole allowing you to connect a pipe with an inside diameter of 17.5mm and 20mm.
Have fun^^
PS: performence is deppending on the flowrate of the airpump. I suggest a 200l/min pump.

description.text: Four bats dangling on a thin threads, creating nice shadows on the wall. The design was inspired by the images made for the unicorn plotter recently on thingiverse. For this bat mobile the same tricks are used to convert a picture into a single line as in the plotter images, but in this case the image is drawn using plastic (PLA/ABS). A total of 5 layers on top of each other gives some strength but leaves a very light object which creates nice shadows. See a very short movie here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=skxY-EhkV6c

IMPORTANT: Before you print the bats from the gcode file you must edit it. The gcode file is created using scripts to convert from an svg to an gcode file directly. The layer thickness is set to 0.3 mm, but parameters like the initial warm up procedure, possible homing, stopping of the heater at the end etc. are NOT included since this is different for each style of printer and for each material. I use a repstrap printer with makerbot electronics and firmware and PLA. Editing is not difficult. Compare a gcode file you have used successfully for some other print and use the header and tail(!) from that to complete the attached gcode file. Print the bat four times. The arms of the mobile are pure filament (PLA/ABS). I used PLA; in case the PLA is too curly from being on a spool, you can easily straighten it by putting it in some hot water in the sink and cooling it down on the sink while pulling it straight. When cooled down the filament will be straight.
The 2 arms are connected by a connector piece, the stl is attached below. Print using you own settings. Four connector pieces are printed in one file because the object is so small; choose the best one, it will need some cleaning up anyway. Check the full size of the lowest image on the left to see what it is supposed to look like. The bats are attached to the arms using some thin thread secured by a tiny drop of glue. I used thin strands of PLA: let the extruder run and manually pull the hot filament out. The faster you pull, the thinner the thread!

title: Nano Quad / Estes Proto X Container

description.text:
This is a simple container for the Revell Nano Quad, Estes Proto X, Hubsan Nano QX... You know, the tiny one ;)
You will need a 3mm pin for the hinges!
The container is made as compact as possible, meaning it only 'just' fits the quad. You will have to take off the rotors, but there is plenty of room inside for both the quad and the rotors.
On the back, there is a hole for the charger.
Some fitting may be required, for instance, depending on the printer resolution, you may have to drill the 3mm holes for the hinge pin in order to get it to fit.
I succesfully printed this thing with a .125 resolution. I will not account for failed prints at lower res.
Sketchup, the quadcopter and a caliper!

title: Dual line laser pointer holder for chinese laser cutter

description.text:
My cheap 40W chinese laser cutter (brand 'ecpur') included a red cross laser pointer for assisting positioning, but it was mounted fiddly and at an angle, so the focus point depends on the object height.
This design replaces the laser pointer with two line-type laser pointers at 90 degree angles. When positioned correctly, the intersection of the two beams matches the cutting point at every object height.
The lasers are enclosed in ball joints for adjustment. Designed for laser pointers of 12mm diameter, these can be bought on ebay from china cheaply.

Designed in OpenJsCad. To modify, edit the .jscad file and go to
http://joostn.github.io/OpenJsCad/processfile.html
to get the STL files.

You can find them if you search eBay or Aliexpress for 'Red Line Laser Module 5v 650nm'.

Vielen Dank für den Lüfterhalter, endlich einer der passt. Meine Teile sehen schon viel besser aus! Ich habe festgestellt, dass es beim Lüfter einen Rückstau gibt. Wenn der Lüfter voll aufgedreht ist, kommt nicht die ganze Ladung Luft durch den Ring, sondern wird beim Lüfter wieder hinausgedrückt. Hast du berechnet, wo der Luftring seinen "Brennpunkt" hat?
Besonders bei hohen und schmalen Teilen, müsste die Luft wirklich ins Zentrum des Hotends blasen.
Ich denke den Ring könnte man ein bisschen dicker konstruieren, so dass mehr Luft durchgehen würde. Ansonsten ist das Teil perfekt! Besonders, dass man den Winkel anpassen kann!

comments.text: Hello, I am new to this and had a couple of questions.  I am using Cura 15.04.2 with a printrbot play. I was looking at the photos above and in the photos there is a support of some sort around the base on the printer bed.  I didnt get anything like that on my finished print.  Do I have to somehow enable this in the software?  Thanks for your help.

comments.text: Love this idea. I'm having trouble printing the bricks on my mini kossel so I'm reverse engineering some of the parts to make some modifications that i think work well for my printer. Just wanted to ask about some design decisions. 1. Why did you opt to make the dimples hollow? does it provide some ability for the dimple to be compressed allowing a tighter fit? 2. why did you opt to make the parts hollow instead of just letting them infill with whatever pattern the user chose? 3. I'm getting cleaner prints with my PLA, maybe just my settings, but I have more colors in PLA. do you prefer ABS because its a little softer and molds a little to the LEGO bricks if the print is a little off? Thanks for the design and thanks for taking the time to answer these questions.

comments.author: Flibbidyfloo

comments.text: Hi there, thank you for downloading our 3D files and the positive comment! The stl files are the latest version 0.9, in which we made some design adjustment for the print supports. They help the studs of the brick to shape better, and they can be removed easier after printing. Some pictures in the gallery were taken earlier, so I figure why they got you kind of confused. Our 3D designs come with the print supports, so it might be unnecessary to add supports. Different printers the result may vary though. But please be sure to have the print supports stand upright on the print bed for printing, as some bricks will lay on the side and some on the end.
comments.author: Flibbidyfloo

comments.text:
Awesome design, I would love to print these out, not sure if the support is necessary, can you make files available without the support?
Slic3r will add its own if required.
comments.author: bobwomble

comments.text: Thanks bobwomble, look forward to your print!  The support design should help and provide a better chance to get a good result. So I would suggest that you print with the support.  The shape of studs will look better with the support. Without proper support, 1x3x1 and 2x4x2 might easily to fall off during printing.

Dockingstation for an Iphone 4.

Print all 3 parts (Dock1.stl, Dock2.stl, Platte.stl).
Glue Dock1.stl and Dock2.stl together. Insert the connector into the long rectangle of Dock2.stl. Insert the Platte.stl into the 2 rectangular holes in Dock2.stl.
By moving the Platte.stl more or less into Dock2.stl you can modify the angle of your phone. Take care, not to stress the connector of your phone...
Perhaps you have to glue them together too when the angle is correct.

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:368375 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=368375

Collapsible landing skids designed for a mini-h frame. Top two pieces have pins which allow the each skid to be rotated and collapsed for transportation. Originally designed to keep the propellers out of the grass on launch, and to avoid general moisture from grass or snow. The was designed for the BAH Nemesis, but can be adapted by adjusting length of 3mm CF rods, aluminum tubes or bamboo skewers (for modeling). Use basic nylon cable clamps to secure to arm bolt.
Only leg tubing is required, but creating a frame strengthens the rigidity of the frame. Additional Hardware:
  • M4 or M3 screw, washer and hex nut (depending on type attachment point of arm).
  • 3mm CF Rod or Aluminum tubing. Bamboo skewers are easy to work with for determining optimal length tubing for skids.
    For the Nemesis: 6mm legs (qty 8) , 12.5mm hinge tube (qty 2), 15mm bottom (qty 2).
  • Hot glue, epoxy... etc.
    • Print Instructions:
  • Choose Hinge / Clamp suitable for frame hardware (M3 or M4) then pick STL orientation which provides the strongest print.
    • Installation:
  • Utilize existing frame hardware for attaching arms. Alternatively drill new holes.
  • Determine top and bottom pairing of printed parts (look for the "O" on the side of the flange).
  • Dry fit all tubing for fit. Flanges on printed part face outward.
  • Use hot glue, epoxy to secure tubing into boots
  • Fit cable clamp over hinge pins. Rounded side of hinge towards skid.
  • Attach skid system to frame. Use existing arm hardware through cable clamps.
    • To-Do Ideas:
  • Develop a lightweight crude retraction with bungie, or silicone tubing. Good for launch and low profile when flying. Bad for landing.
  • Make asymmetrical boots and hinge.
  • Make variation of boot to accommodate a through hole design for longer bottom tubes.

Installation:
  • Utilize existing frame hardware for attaching arms. Alternatively drill new holes.
  • Determine top and bottom pairing of printed parts (look for the "O" on the side of the flange).
  • Dry fit all tubing for fit. Flanges on printed part face outward.
  • Use hot glue, epoxy to secure tubing into boots
  • Fit cable clamp over hinge pins. Rounded side of hinge towards skid.
  • Attach skid system to frame. Use existing arm hardware through cable clamps.

This is the rotor block for the mendocino motor. The hole is 3/8" and is sized for a standard dowel. The magnets I've used have an interior dimension of 3/8". Wire is wrapped in the grooves, and solar cells are mounted on the flats. The way I have made the mendo motor in the past depended on a 1" balsa block with a similar shape. The grooves were put in with a router table and custom jig. The center hole was done with a drill press. I don't have access to those tools, so am developing this as a way of making the motor without use of the woodshop tools. Here is an article on the Mendo Motor: http://fussingwithstuff.com/2008/06/mendocino-motor.html

Make it on the Makerbot or similar tool. Insert an 8" long 3/8" dowel. Wrap two lengths of 50' long magnet wire. solder the cells to the ends of the wire. Assemble the rotor on the base using 1 1/18" x 1/4" ceramic magnets.

remixed_from.author: GregFrost
remixed_from.title: Parametric Involute  Bevel and Spur Gears

description.text: My variation on the iris box that uses gears to drive the blades.

I wanted an iris box that worked with gears so I could open and close it with a servo. This is my first attempt and is still rough. But mechanically it does work so I wanted to upload it and let others make derivatives if they want. I made nut traps but I made them pentagons instead of hexagons so they are pretty useless. The base is thicker than it needs to be too. I used the greg frost gear scripts to make the gears http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3575. A few things I figured out that can help others do the same. You need a radius on the small gears that allow the iris to be the correct size. The distance from one iris blade's axis to the outside edge of the adjacent blade's gear should be close to the distance from the blade's axis to the middle of the box. The number of teeth in your outer gear should be a multiple of 5. This will let you design one blade in blender and then spin duplicate it. It also allows the blades to be interchangeable. Otherwise you would have to number the blades and install them in exact order.
There is a spot for a 6th axis. If you just print one of the gears from the blades you should be able to drive the whole box with a servo. This hasn't been tested yet as I wanted to do a quick mechanical test and didn't design a servo mount.

author: mechadense

description.text:
Glowing mushroom for your desktop that is powered by any colored LED and batteries(or usb).
The legend says that:
  • Green mushrooms are magical
  • Blue mushrooms are ghostly
  • Red mushrooms are poisonous / viking fuel ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amanita_muscaria )
    Designed to be printed with PLA and to fit 2x 2032 lithium 3v batteries, a switch, led and a resistor. The leg of the mushroom is hollowed (3mm) for the wires and the resistor.
    Batteries are neatly hidden under the base. Switch is behind the base.
    Works ok as a ornament when printed with nontransparent plastic.
    (as a side idea the glow was to be produced with a UV led and with a glow in the dark plastic..could still work)

• Print all the parts (unsupported or supported->leg.stl)
  • Clean well (the lid and its tracks are hard but they\\'ll work)
  • Do all the top solderings (led+resistor*+wires)
  • Cut the led and resistor legs short(5mm from top..or so)
  • Solder the black wire to the cathode (shorter leg)
  • Solder the anode (longer leg +) to the shortened resistor and the wire
  • Insert the top assembly correctly from the top (wires first)
  • Cut and run the wire from the side to the switch** and solder
  • Glue the switch in place (legs and all)
  • Strip the wire from switch bare, solder and turn it in to a coil for a contactor.
  • Cut black wire approx. 20mm from the hole and strip. Solder and turn it to a contactor.
    *resistor formula..
    power voltage(V) - led voltage(V)
    ------------------------------------ = Resistor (Ohm)
    amps used by led (A) (usually 0.02A)
    **switch
    The switch used is made from circuit board multi switch by sawing. (just cut one of them free with hack saw.) be careful with the legs, they are fragile, I wasted mine cos I did not glue it well enough...

author: petrex

description.text:
This is a simple project to make a shoerack out of cheap, readily-available materials. The only 3d printed part is a clip to bind everything together.  
Full disclosure: this was not my original idea. I came across similar projects on various blogs. This is just my execution of the idea.
What I love about this project is that it's simple, cheap, and aesthetically playful.

For the tubes, I used concrete forming tubes. Make sure you compare the individual tubes you're buying at the store since they don't always match up exactly. You may have to pull out several to find a few that are close enough. To attach the tubes, you can just use regular binder clips available at any office supply store. I decided that I wanted the clips to match the tubes (which I painted white externally), but white binder clips are hard to come by. So, I ended up printing out clips (model file attached) and used white filament to get the look I was going for.

• Cut the concrete tubes into ~1ft lengths. I used a carpenter's knife for this step, and it was a pain. If you have a band saw at your disposal, I highly recommend using it.

  • Use an exacto or carpenter's knife to clean up the edges of the tubes.

  • Paint the tubes. I used basic house paint here - white for the exteriors, and a wedge of 3 different greens for the interior. You'll want to use at least two coats.

  • After the paint dries, assemble the tubes in a hexagonal pattern, adding a clip at every junction between two tubes.
This holder allows you to fix the camera atop your screen. The design is done to support most flat screens as the clamp width can be set with a thumbwheel.

Use 2x M3 nuts, a fitting washer and a M3 screw to fix the moving parts. Glue the top part to the rest. You'll figure it out ;-)
If your nut doesn't fit good (e.g., it has too much room) use the extra stl file provided or make your own stl from the provided source file.

scan your fingerprint, make a unique phone case!

This is not my idea, I saw it at http://polychemy.com/products/iphone-4-finger-print-case. However, I thought it was a shame not to actually have your own fingerprint on the case. People have already suggested it's possibly not wise to broadcast your fingerprint. It's my understanding that a system relying on an image of a fingerprint based security is already broken: http://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2009/01/biometrics.html This is not a finished product, it's a proof of concept. Some work is required before you could actually print this for your model of phone. Someone please fork the repo and add some real cases! Get all the files from here: https://github.com/mattvenn/fingerprintcase
